node.title: They Had Reasons for Leaving the City. So Why Are Their Friends Mad?
node.alt: “I always look for the best in New York, and there I was leaving — like a deserter,” said Joel Schnell, who moved to Lauderdale-by-the-Sea, Fla., during the pandemic, with his wife, Lynne White.
node.description: When Covid hit, some New Yorkers abandoned the city for good. They left some angry friends.
node.content: ["Jordan Frey moved to Manhattan from Rochester, N.Y., in July of 2013 for his residency in plastic surgery and a subsequent fellowship. He and his wife, Selenid Gonzalez-Frey, rented a two-bedroom apartment in Murray Hill, delighted to be in a city with so much to offer.", "Seven years later, as Dr. Frey neared the end of his training, a decision loomed: Was he going to remain in town and establish a practice, or settle elsewhere? \u201cWe really thought we were going to stay,\u201d he said.", "But it was complicated. New York City was alluring, but by then the couple had two children, and they couldn\u2019t deny the appeal of raising them in a place where wide-open spaces were just outside the front or back door.", "Covid crystallized things. \u201cThe activities our kids were doing got closed, and we felt pretty claustrophobic,\u201d said Dr. Frey, 34. \u201cWe thought that if we went somewhere else we\u2019d be able to afford not just more room but a much nicer place.\u201d", "In July of 2020, the family moved to Buffalo, where Dr. Frey grew up and where Ms. Gonzalez-Frey, 34, is now an assistant professor of education at the State University of New York. Home is a four-bedroom colonial on a one-acre lot.", "The Freys were among the more than 837,400 people who submitted change-of-address requests from New York City addresses in 2020, a 36 percent increase over 2019, according to a pandemic migration report from the NYC office of the comptroller, citing United States Postal Service data. The figure was particularly stark in March of 2020, when almost 80,000 move-out forms were filed, a 65 percent spike from the previous March.", "Many of those who beat their way to the exits, maybe to weekend or vacation houses to escape Covid \u2014 and who took a lot of flak for it \u2014 have since returned to the city. They never planned to be gone forever. Can\u2019t quit you, baby, and all that. But some who left during the pandemic have made the move permanent \u2014 and they\u2019re dealing with the fallout.", "Take the Freys. They\u2019re very happy with the move, but their New York City friends aren\u2019t so happy with them. Covid is a passing thing, they told the couple, but New York is forever. They would regret what they were doing, the doomsayers warned, noting the folly of making a consequential decision based on a temporary situation.", "\u201cThere was a real sense that they felt betrayed,\u201d said Dr. Frey, who is now on the staff of Erie County Medical Center, and who recently started The Prudent Plastic Surgeon, an investment advice website aimed at his fellow doctors. \u201cWe got a lot of, \u2018How can you leave? New York is struggling, and you need to be supportive. And it was made clear to me that I wasn\u2019t doing that. Our way of handling it was to emphasize to our friends that we loved New York City and that we weren\u2019t abandoning it in a time of need. But we still felt judged.\u201d", "Of course, moving is always a big deal, and not just for the people who are boxing up their possessions. The ground also trembles under the feet of the friends who remain behind, and who could be forgiven for feeling that U-Haul is breaking up the old gang.", "But when the city that\u2019s being left is New York, the level of attendant annoyance seems especially high; it feels like a personal insult to friends of the soon-to-be ex-resident. Now factor in the pandemic, and distress starts moving into the red zone \u2014 indignation.", "\u201cThe people who moved out of New York during Covid made the decision that the city wasn\u2019t safe enough, wasn\u2019t appealing enough, wasn\u2019t good enough, was too expensive,\u201d said Gail Saltz, a clinical associate professor of psychiatry at the NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center. \u201cAnd their friends may see that as an indictment of their own choice, especially if they\u2019re ambivalent about their choice. A defense might be, \u2018I\u2019m a loyal person and I\u2019m being loyal to my city, and you all are abandoning it.\u2019\u201d", "The abandonment charge was especially painful for Joel Schnell, 72, a lifelong New Yorker \u2014 that is, until last year, when he lost his income and also became increasingly concerned about his 97-year-old mother living alone in Florida.", "\u201cSo: pandemic, no income, my mother \u2026 We thought it was time to go to the beach and hide,\u201d said Mr. Schell, who works in women\u2019s fashion. \u201cThe truth is we were scared being in New York.\u201d", "The pandemic was raging in November of 2020 \u2014 and so, as a matter of fact, were some of Mr. Schnell\u2019s friends \u2014 when he and his wife, Lynne White, a former news anchor, sold their co-op on the Lower East Side and lit out for a two-bedroom rental in Lauderdale-by-the-Sea.", "\u201cOur friends were like, \u2018We\u2019re not out from under this, and New Yorkers should stick together. We stuck together through 9/11 and through the financial crisis in 2008, so why are you moving?\u2019\u201d Ms. White said.", "One of Mr. Schnell\u2019s pals told him they were making \u201ca harsh mistake\u201d by leaving. \u201cIt was almost like a guilt trip, and it did make me feel guilty,\u201d he said.", "Adding insult to injury, the elder of his two daughters piled on. \u201cShe said, \u2018I know you\u2019re doing what you have to do, but I\u2019m disappointed that you\u2019re not here for us,\u2019\u201d Mr. Schnell recalled. Even his dry cleaner gave him grief.", "True, some who left might still be in New York if not for the pandemic. Others were already thinking it was time to move on and move away, and Covid was the event that pushed them over the edge. Perhaps they wanted more space. Perhaps they wanted a lower cost of living. Now they were able to work remotely, so why not live somewhere else?", "But whatever their reasons for leaving, they left some irate friends.", "\u201cCovid was the last straw for some people in my neighborhood,\u201d said Lazarus Jackson, 39, a truck driver who lives in a rental in the Bronx. \u201cThey were like, \u2018I don\u2019t want to be here anymore,\u2019 and they sold their house and left. I\u2019m not happy with these people at all. It\u2019s breaking a bond. We\u2019ve been friends for 20, 25 years.\u201d", "For him, the distress goes beyond the personal. He sees his neighborhood in jeopardy. \u201cI tell my friends, \u2018There was a lot that went into you having that house in the first place. It\u2019s been in your family since the \u201960s. A lot of sacrifices were made for you to have it. Why sell it?\u2019\u201d he said.", "\u201cWhen people leave the community \u2014 this isn\u2019t a gentrified area \u2014 it\u2019s not like things get better,\u201d Mr. Jackson continued. \u201cSo when my friends say, \u2018I just want to get out of the city,\u2019 I just think it\u2019s a pretty short-term way of looking at things.\u201d", "Until the pandemic hit, Grace MacDougall had no plans to leave Manhattan, where she and her best friend from high school shared a two-bedroom rental in a walk-up building in Five Points. But once she realized that she liked working remotely, and saw how much she could save on rent, well, cue the moving van.", "\u201cBut my roommate was so upset. She hated the fact that I left and hated the fact that I left during Covid,\u201d said Ms. MacDougall, 27, the marketing and growth manager for a start-up, who tested positive for the virus during the first week of the pandemic. \u201cShe had convinced me to move to New York in the first place. She had shown me the ropes, the ins and outs. She felt that I was breaking up with her, but also that I was breaking up with the greatest city in the world. It put a strain on our relationship.\u201d", "There is, in all of this, some element of \u201cLove me, love my city.\u201d", "\u201cIf you identify with where you live, that place becomes personified, \u201cDr. Saltz said. \u201cNew York is the place. People who left seem to reject the very thing their friends love, and the reaction can be, \u2018How dare you reject my favorite thing? How dare you turn your back on my identity?\u2019\u201d", "\u201cThere are so many complicated feelings involved with leaving New York,\u201d said Emily Stockton-Brown, 31, a senior account supervisor for a public-relations firm, who moved to New York in 2015 and lived in a series of studio apartments in Brooklyn before moving to Union Square, where she and her partner, Zach Honig, rented a triplex with another couple. \u201cWe didn\u2019t want to be living in studio apartments during Covid, and the place in Union Square was gorgeous.\u201d", "But it was a temporary fix. This past May, with permission to work remotely, she and Mr. Honig, who works in financial technology, relocated to Philadelphia to be closer to their families and bought a three-bedroom condo. (They also recently got engaged.) \u201cWe would never have been able to purchase such a property in New York,\u201d Ms. Stockton-Brown said.", "For a while, she kept the news from her local best friend, who had already been aggravated enough when Ms. Stockton-Brown took a pandemic break from the city to spend some time at a rental cabin in Maine.", "\u201cI finally had a glass of wine, got up my gumption and called her,\u201d she said. \u201cWe had a little cry together, but then things got a little tense. She felt that, for whatever reason, we were choosing not to be in the center of the universe anymore. She took it very personally and said, \u2018Oh, here I am now by myself.\u2019\u201d", "That anger can cut both ways.", "So, Tyrone Evans Clark\u2019s friends are mad at him for leaving their shared rental in Brooklyn and moving to Los Angeles when the pandemic hit? Well, he\u2019s mad at them for being mad. Sure, he understands that they were a happy tribe of misfits and starving artists (Mr. Clark is an actor), and he was breaking up the clique. But why couldn\u2019t they understand his situation?", "\u201cHow did they expect me to keep paying the rent when I didn\u2019t have any money?\u201d asked Mr. Clark, 35. \u201cI\u2019m upset that they didn\u2019t get my dilemma.\u201d", "Three months after Ms. Stockton-Brown moved to Philadelphia, her censorious friend sheepishly called to say she and her partner had just moved to Portland, Maine. Ms. Stockton-Brown is overjoyed for her.", "As for Mr. Schnell, he makes sure to wear a New York Mets or New York Giants T-shirt when he works out in Florida. \u201cWe don\u2019t know how yet, but we\u2019re going to move back to the city someday,\u201d he said.", "And more than a year on, Dr. Frey thinks his friends\u2019 stance may have softened a bit. \u201cThey still think we\u2019re dumb for leaving,\u201d he said. \u201cBut I don\u2019t think they\u2019re still mad. We haven\u2019t been back to the city yet, but they want to hang out with us when we do.\u201d", "His friends are also welcome to hang out with him upstate, Dr. Frey added, \u201cbut they aren\u2019t talking about coming to Buffalo.\u201d"]
